question_text_latex: \textbf{Statements:}\\ 1. Some actors are singers.\\ 2. All the singers are dancers.\\ \\ \textbf{Conclusions:}\\ I. Some actors are dancers.\\ II. No singer is an actor.\\ \\ Which conclusion follows?
explanation_latex: Since some actors are singers ($A \cap S \neq \emptyset$) and all singers are dancers ($S \subseteq D$), the intersection of Actors and Dancers is not empty. Therefore, 'Some actors are dancers' is definitely true. Conclusion II is false because we already know some singers (who are actors) exist.

question_text_latex: Read the following data:\\ Total students = $1000$.\\ \textbf{Stream distribution:} Science ($40\%$), Commerce ($35\%$), Arts ($25\%$).\\ Girls in Science = $200$.\\ Girls in Commerce = $150$.\\ Girls in Arts = $100$.\\ \\ What is the ratio of Boys in Science to Boys in Arts?
explanation_latex: Total Science = $40\%$ of $1000 = 400$. Boys in Science = $400 - 200$ (Girls) = $200$.\\ Total Arts = $25\%$ of $1000 = 250$. Boys in Arts = $250 - 100$ (Girls) = $150$.\\ Ratio = $200 : 150 = 4 : 3$.

question_text_latex: Pointing to a photograph, Rajesh said, ``She is the daughter of my grandfather's only son.'' How is the woman in the photograph related to Rajesh?
explanation_latex: My grandfather's only son = My father. The daughter of my father = My sister. Therefore, the woman is Rajesh's sister.

question_text_latex: Kavita walks $5$ km towards North, then turns left and walks $3$ km. She then turns right and walks $4$ km. Finally, she turns right again and walks $6$ km. How far is she from her starting point and in which direction?
explanation_latex: Net vertical displacement = $5 + 4 = 9$ km North. Net horizontal displacement = $3 - 6 = -3$ km ($3$ km West). Distance = $\sqrt{9^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{81 + 9} = \sqrt{90} = 3\sqrt{10}$ km. Direction is North-East from starting point.

question_text_latex: In a certain code language, 'COMPUTER' is written as 'DPNQVUFS'. How is 'SCIENCE' written in that code?
explanation_latex: Each letter is replaced by the next letter in the alphabet. $C \rightarrow D$, $O \rightarrow P$, $M \rightarrow N$, etc. Similarly, $S \rightarrow T$, $C \rightarrow D$, $I \rightarrow J$, $E \rightarrow F$, $N \rightarrow O$, $C \rightarrow D$, $E \rightarrow F$. So 'SCIENCE' becomes 'TDJFODF'.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``The company has decided to conduct aptitude tests for all new recruits.''\\ \\ \textbf{Assumptions:}\\ I. The company wants to ensure quality hiring.\\ II. Aptitude tests can measure candidate suitability.\\ \\ Which assumption(s) is/are implicit?
explanation_latex: Both assumptions are implicit. The company conducts aptitude tests assuming they help in quality hiring (I) and that such tests can effectively measure suitability (II).

question_text_latex: A company has three departments: HR, IT, and Finance. Total employees = $240$.\\ HR has $25\%$ of total employees.\\ IT has $40\%$ of total employees.\\ The average salary in HR is Rs. $35{,}000$.\\ The average salary in IT is Rs. $55{,}000$.\\ The average salary in Finance is Rs. $42{,}000$.\\ \\ What is the overall average salary of all employees?
Find the next number in the series: $3, 7, 15, 31, 63, ?$
explanation_latex: Pattern: Each number = (Previous number $\times 2$) $+ 1$. $3 \times 2 + 1 = 7$, $7 \times 2 + 1 = 15$, $15 \times 2 + 1 = 31$, $31 \times 2 + 1 = 63$, $63 \times 2 + 1 = 127$.

question_text_latex: Six friends P, Q, R, S, T, and U are sitting in a row facing North. P is to the immediate left of Q. R is not at any end. S is second to the right of T. U is to the immediate right of S. Who is sitting at the extreme right?
explanation_latex: From the clues: S is second to right of T, U is immediate right of S. This gives T \_ S U. P is immediate left of Q gives P Q. R is not at ends. Arrangement: T P Q R S U or similar. U is at extreme right.

question_text_latex: Book : Pages :: Tree : ?
explanation_latex: A book is made up of pages. Similarly, a tree has leaves. The relationship is whole to its parts.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statements:}\\ 1. All managers are leaders.\\ 2. Some leaders are visionaries.\\ \\ \textbf{Conclusions:}\\ I. Some managers are visionaries.\\ II. All visionaries are managers.\\ \\ Which conclusion follows?
explanation_latex: From the statements, we cannot establish a definite relationship between managers and visionaries. Some leaders could be visionaries but not managers. Therefore, neither conclusion follows.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Sales Data (in Lakhs):}\\ \\ \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|c|} \hline Product & Q1 & Q2 & Q3 & Q4 \\ \hline Laptops & 120 & 135 & 150 & 165 \\ \hline Mobiles & 200 & 220 & 210 & 230 \\ \hline Tablets & 80 & 95 & 110 & 125 \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \\ What is the percentage increase in total sales from Q1 to Q4?
explanation_latex: Q1 total = $120 + 200 + 80 = 400$ lakhs. Q4 total = $165 + 230 + 125 = 520$ lakhs. Increase = $520 - 400 = 120$ lakhs. Percentage = $\frac{120}{400} \times 100 = 30\%$.

question_text_latex: Find the next term in the series: A, D, G, J, M, ?
explanation_latex: Pattern: Each letter is $3$ positions ahead in the alphabet. $A(+3) \rightarrow D(+3) \rightarrow G(+3) \rightarrow J(+3) \rightarrow M(+3) \rightarrow P$.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``The government has increased funding for public schools by $20\%$.''\\ \\ \textbf{Conclusions:}\\ I. The quality of education will improve.\\ II. The government is prioritizing education.\\ \\ Which conclusion(s) logically follow(s)?
explanation_latex: Conclusion II directly follows from the action of increased funding showing priority. Conclusion I is a possibility but not a definite logical conclusion as funding alone doesn't guarantee quality improvement. Therefore, only II follows.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statements:}\\ 1. No flower is red.\\ 2. Some roses are flowers.\\ 3. All roses are beautiful.\\ \\ \textbf{Conclusions:}\\ I. Some beautiful things are not red.\\ II. No rose is red.\\ \\ Which conclusion follows?
explanation_latex: Since some roses are flowers and no flower is red, those roses cannot be red. All roses are beautiful, so some beautiful things (roses) are not red. Both conclusions follow.

question_text_latex: A library has $5000$ books distributed as follows:\\ Fiction: $35\%$, Non-Fiction: $28\%$, Academic: $22\%$, Reference: $15\%$.\\ If $40\%$ of Fiction books and $60\%$ of Academic books are borrowed, how many books remain in the library?
explanation_latex: Fiction = $35\%$ of $5000 = 1750$. Borrowed Fiction = $40\%$ of $1750 = 700$. Academic = $22\%$ of $5000 = 1100$. Borrowed Academic = $60\%$ of $1100 = 660$. Total borrowed = $700 + 660 = 1360$. Remaining = $5000 - 1360 = 3640$.

question_text_latex: Introducing Meera, Sameer said, ``Her mother's brother is the father of my son.'' How is Meera related to Sameer?
explanation_latex: The father of Sameer's son = Sameer himself. So Meera's mother's brother = Sameer. This means Meera's mother is Sameer's sister. Therefore, Meera is Sameer's niece.

question_text_latex: Find the next term: 2A, 4C, 8E, 16G, ?
explanation_latex: Number pattern: $2, 4, 8, 16$ (multiply by $2$) $\rightarrow$ next is $32$. Letter pattern: A, C, E, G (skip one letter) $\rightarrow$ next is I. Answer: $32$I.

question_text_latex: If 'BANGALORE' is coded as 'CBOHMPSFF', how is 'DELHI' coded?
explanation_latex: Each letter is replaced by the next letter: $B \rightarrow C$, $A \rightarrow B$, $N \rightarrow O$, etc. Similarly, $D \rightarrow E$, $E \rightarrow F$, $L \rightarrow M$, $H \rightarrow I$, $I \rightarrow J$. 'DELHI' becomes 'EFMIJ'.

question_text_latex: Eight people A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H are sitting around a circular table facing the center. A is second to the right of D. C is third to the left of A. E is opposite to C. G is between E and B. F is not adjacent to D. Who is sitting opposite to B?
explanation_latex: Working through the constraints: A is 2nd right of D, C is 3rd left of A (or 5th right), E opposite C, G between E and B. After arranging: D \_ A \_ C \_ E \_. G is between E and B. F not adjacent to D. Final arrangement places F opposite to B.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``Should school uniforms be made mandatory in all schools?''\\ \\ \textbf{Arguments:}\\ I. Yes, it promotes equality among students.\\ II. No, it restricts individual expression.\\ \\ Which argument is strong?
explanation_latex: Both arguments present valid viewpoints. Argument I addresses social equality, while argument II addresses personal freedom. Both are strong arguments from different perspectives.

question_text_latex: Find the odd one out: $17, 23, 37, 43, 51$
explanation_latex: All numbers except $51$ are prime numbers. $51 = 3 \times 17$, so it is composite. Therefore, $51$ is the odd one out.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Production Data (in Tonnes):}\\ \\ \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|c|} \hline Factory & Jan & Feb & Mar & Apr \\ \hline F1 & 450 & 480 & 520 & 550 \\ \hline F2 & 380 & 420 & 450 & 490 \\ \hline F3 & 520 & 540 & 580 & 600 \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \\ Which factory showed the highest percentage growth from Jan to Apr?
Ravi starts from his home and walks $8$ km South, then turns left and walks $6$ km. He then turns left again and walks $12$ km. How far is he from his starting point?
explanation_latex: Net South displacement = $8 - 12 = -4$ km ($4$ km North). Net East displacement = $6$ km. Distance = $\sqrt{4^2 + 6^2} = \sqrt{16 + 36} = \sqrt{52} = 2\sqrt{13}$ km.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``Traffic congestion has increased significantly in the city.''\\ \\ \textbf{Courses of Action:}\\ I. Increase public transport facilities.\\ II. Ban all private vehicles.\\ \\ Which course of action should be followed?
explanation_latex: Increasing public transport (I) is a practical solution. Banning all private vehicles (II) is extreme and impractical. Therefore, only I should be followed.

question_text_latex: Find the missing number: $5, 10, 20, 35, 55, ?$
explanation_latex: Pattern: Differences are $5, 10, 15, 20, 25$ (arithmetic progression). Next difference = $25$. So $55 + 25 = 80$.

question_text_latex: A school conducted exams in three subjects. Total students = $600$.\\ - $70\%$ passed in Math\\ - $75\%$ passed in Science\\ - $80\%$ passed in English\\ - $50\%$ passed in all three subjects\\ \\ How many students passed in at least two subjects?
explanation_latex: Using inclusion-exclusion: Let $x$ = students passing at least $2$ subjects. Students passing all $3$ = $50\%$ = $300$. Math pass = $420$, Science = $450$, English = $480$. Using Venn diagram logic: Students passing at least $2$ = $540$.

question_text_latex: Doctor : Patient :: Teacher : ?
explanation_latex: A doctor treats a patient. Similarly, a teacher teaches a student. The relationship is professional to the person they serve.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statements:}\\ 1. All cats are animals.\\ 2. Some animals are wild.\\ \\ \textbf{Conclusions:}\\ I. Some cats are wild.\\ II. All wild things are animals.\\ \\ Which conclusion follows?
explanation_latex: We cannot establish that some cats are wild from the given statements. Conclusion II is also not derivable as we only know some animals are wild, not all wild things are animals. Neither follows.

question_text_latex: Find the next term: Z, X, V, T, R, ?
explanation_latex: Pattern: Each letter moves $2$ positions backward in the alphabet. $Z(-2) \rightarrow X(-2) \rightarrow V(-2) \rightarrow T(-2) \rightarrow R(-2) \rightarrow P$.

question_text_latex: Seven people J, K, L, M, N, O, P are sitting in a straight line facing North (not necessarily in same order). L sits fourth to the right of J. M sits at one of the extreme ends. Only two people sit between M and K. N sits second to the left of P. Who sits exactly in the middle?
explanation_latex: With $7$ people, middle position is 4th. From clues: M at end, L is 4th right of J, $2$ between M and K, N 2nd left of P. Working through: M \_ \_ K \_ \_ \_ or similar arrangements lead to L being in the middle (4th position).

question_text_latex: A company's revenue in 2024 was Rs. $80$ lakhs. In 2025, it increased by $25\%$. In 2026, it decreased by $20\%$ from 2025. What is the revenue in 2026?
A is B's sister. C is B's mother. D is C's father. E is D's mother. How is A related to D?
explanation_latex: A is B's sister, B is C's child, C is D's child. Therefore, A is D's granddaughter.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``Join our coding bootcamp to become a software engineer in 6 months.''\\ \\ \textbf{Assumptions:}\\ I. People want to become software engineers quickly.\\ II. A 6-month bootcamp is sufficient for software engineering.\\ \\ Which assumption(s) is/are implicit?
explanation_latex: The advertisement assumes people desire quick entry into software engineering (I) and that their bootcamp duration is adequate (II). Both assumptions are implicit.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Student Marks:}\\ \\ \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|} \hline Student & Math & Physics & Chemistry \\ \hline Arun & 85 & 78 & 92 \\ \hline Bina & 92 & 85 & 88 \\ \hline Chetan & 78 & 92 & 85 \\ \hline Diya & 88 & 88 & 78 \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \\ If the weightage is Math:Physics:Chemistry = $2:2:1$, who has the highest weighted average?
explanation_latex: Arun: $\frac{85 \times 2 + 78 \times 2 + 92 \times 1}{5} = \frac{170+156+92}{5} = \frac{418}{5} = 83.6$. Bina: $\frac{92 \times 2 + 85 \times 2 + 88 \times 1}{5} = \frac{184+170+88}{5} = \frac{442}{5} = 88.4$. Chetan: $\frac{78 \times 2 + 92 \times 2 + 85 \times 1}{5} = \frac{156+184+85}{5} = \frac{425}{5} = 85$. Diya: $\frac{88 \times 2 + 88 \times 2 + 78 \times 1}{5} = \frac{176+176+78}{5} = \frac{430}{5} = 86$. All have different averages.

question_text_latex: Find the next term: 1Z, 3Y, 5X, 7W, ?
explanation_latex: Number pattern: $1, 3, 5, 7$ (add $2$) $\rightarrow$ next is $9$. Letter pattern: Z, Y, X, W (move backward) $\rightarrow$ next is V. Answer: $9$V.

question_text_latex: In a code language, 'FRIEND' is written as 'GSJFOE'. How is 'MENTOR' written?
explanation_latex: Pattern: Each letter is replaced by next letter. $F \rightarrow G$, $R \rightarrow S$, $I \rightarrow J$, $E \rightarrow F$, $N \rightarrow O$, $D \rightarrow E$. So $M \rightarrow N$, $E \rightarrow F$, $N \rightarrow O$, $T \rightarrow U$, $O \rightarrow P$, $R \rightarrow S$ = NFOUPS.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statements:}\\ 1. Some phones are smart.\\ 2. All smart things are expensive.\\ 3. No expensive thing is durable.\\ \\ \textbf{Conclusions:}\\ I. Some phones are expensive.\\ II. No smart phone is durable.\\ \\ Which conclusion follows?
explanation_latex: Some phones are smart, and all smart things are expensive, so some phones are expensive (I follows). Since smart things are expensive and no expensive thing is durable, smart phones cannot be durable (II follows). Both follow.

question_text_latex: A survey of $500$ people revealed:\\ - $280$ like Tea\\ - $220$ like Coffee\\ - $150$ like both Tea and Coffee\\ \\ How many people like neither Tea nor Coffee?
explanation_latex: Using set theory: Tea only = $280-150 = 130$. Coffee only = $220-150 = 70$. Both = $150$. Total liking at least one = $130+70+150 = 350$. Neither = $500-350 = 150$.

question_text_latex: Priya walks $10$ m towards East, then turns right and walks $20$ m, then turns right again and walks $10$ m. In which direction is she from her starting point?
explanation_latex: Starting point: $(0,0)$. After $10$m East: $(10,0)$. After $20$m South: $(10,-20)$. After $10$m West: $(0,-20)$. She is $20$m South of starting point.

question_text_latex: Find the missing number: $1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, ?$
Five persons A, B, C, D, E are sitting around a circular table. A is to the immediate left of B. C is second to the right of B. D is not adjacent to C. Where is E sitting?
explanation_latex: A is immediate left of B means: A-B. C is 2nd right of B means: B-?-C. With $5$ people in circle: A-B-E-C-D. Since D not adjacent to C: arrangement is valid. E is between B and D (going around).

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``All successful students study regularly.''\\ \\ \textbf{Conclusions:}\\ I. Regular study leads to success.\\ II. Students who don't study regularly cannot be successful.\\ \\ Which conclusion(s) follow(s)?
explanation_latex: The statement tells us successful students study regularly, but doesn't confirm that regular study guarantees success (I is not proven). However, II is a contrapositive and could be considered. Actually, neither follows definitively as we cannot confirm causation from the given statement alone.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Monthly Expenses (in Rs.):}\\ \\ \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|c|} \hline Month & Rent & Food & Transport & Others \\ \hline Jan & 8000 & 5000 & 2000 & 3000 \\ \hline Feb & 8000 & 5500 & 2200 & 3200 \\ \hline Mar & 8000 & 6000 & 2500 & 3500 \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \\ What is the average monthly expense?
Train : Track :: Ship : ?
explanation_latex: A train moves on a track. Similarly, a ship moves on the sea. The relationship is vehicle to the medium it travels on.

question_text_latex: A company produces three products X, Y, Z.\\ Total production cost = Rs. $50$ lakhs.\\ Cost ratio X:Y:Z = $3:2:5$.\\ Selling prices: X at $40\%$ profit, Y at $25\%$ profit, Z at $30\%$ profit.\\ \\ What is the total profit earned?
explanation_latex: Total cost = $50$ lakhs. X cost = $\frac{3}{10} \times 50 = 15$ lakhs. Y cost = $\frac{2}{10} \times 50 = 10$ lakhs. Z cost = $\frac{5}{10} \times 50 = 25$ lakhs. Profit on X = $40\%$ of $15 = 6$ lakhs. Profit on Y = $25\%$ of $10 = 2.5$ lakhs. Profit on Z = $30\%$ of $25 = 7.5$ lakhs. Total profit = $6+2.5+7.5 = 16$ lakhs.

question_text_latex: Find the odd one out: $121, 144, 169, 196, 200$
explanation_latex: All numbers except $200$ are perfect squares. $121=11^2$, $144=12^2$, $169=13^2$, $196=14^2$. $200$ is not a perfect square.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``Many employees are resigning due to work-life imbalance.''\\ \\ \textbf{Courses of Action:}\\ I. Introduce flexible working hours.\\ II. Fire the HR department.\\ \\ Which course of action is appropriate?
explanation_latex: Flexible working hours (I) directly addresses work-life balance. Firing HR (II) is irrational and doesn't solve the problem. Only I is appropriate.

question_text_latex: Karan said, ``This girl is the wife of the grandson of my mother.'' How is Karan related to the girl?
explanation_latex: Grandson of Karan's mother = Karan's nephew or Karan's son. If it's Karan's son, then Karan is the father-in-law of the girl. Most logical interpretation: Father-in-law.

question_text_latex: \textbf{Statement:} ``Should students be allowed to use smartphones in classrooms?''\\ \\ \textbf{Arguments:}\\ I. Yes, smartphones can be educational tools for quick information access.\\ II. No, they distract students from learning.\\ III. Yes, it prepares students for technology-driven workplaces.\\ \\ Which arguments are strong?
explanation_latex: All three arguments present valid perspectives. I highlights educational benefits, II addresses distraction concerns, III considers future readiness. All are strong arguments from different viewpoints.
